page.title: 14UNDERCLIFFE CEMETERY
page.content:
On its opening in {1884,} it was described as{"one of the most striking {and beautiful features of the town." In its 25 acres, planned by landscape gardener W.Gay,are many fine monuments of granite,marble and stone. These were put up in memory of dead citizens some of whom are famous in the history of Bradford {e.g. Mawson, joint {architect of the Wool Exchange & the {Town Hall; Milligan, the First Mayor; {& Illingworth, a textile manufacturer.
The cemetery is now no longer used for burials. Although the views over the city are still magnificent, the grounds themselves in recent years have become neglected. Fortunately, public concern to preserve the cemetery as a piece of local History has led to its purchase by the Council with plans to restore it.
